parameters: \pop[2]We all sit around the hotel room, engrossed in our campaign.
\pop[2]Things sure have progressed since we started. I'm really invested.
\pop[5]Well then, you struck a deal with the leader of The Thorns.
It seems like they're willing to negotiate things with Isaac.
I thought we were in a prison cell.
\pop[5]I had to expedite things a bit.
\pop[4]Wow, I'm sure glad we got out of that prison cell.
Being locked up with Dante sure is a special kind of torture.
If this deal goes south, you'll all die.
\pop[3]What \c[14]is\c[0] the nature of this deal, anyway?
\pop[4]Well, it's basically a stalemate right now.
We both have enough dirt to ruin each other.
\pop[4]So, I'm gonna ask them to drop it.
\pop[3]And the town square is the best place for that?
\pop[4]Wait. I thought we were gonna bring them in.
We have enough info to bring down their \c[14]entire\c[0] organization.
In a situation like this, it's best to trade discretion.
We could take them down, but we can \c[14]never\c[0] erase info.
And yeah, the town square \c[14]is\c[0] the best spot.
Too open for an ambush, and we're keeping civilians at a distance.
\pop[4]I hope they show up this time.
\pop[4]Last time I arranged a meeting, it didn't go so well.
Thankfully, The Monarch had my back.
\i[3]"That was a different kind of meeting, Isaac."
\i[3]"That was a different kind of meeting, Isaac."
But it's good to have some moral support either way.
Especially when there's so much on the line.
\pop[4]Yeah. But by now, we're experts at it.
Besides, they agreed to show up before nightfall.
It lessens the risk of an ambush on \c[14]either\c[0] side.
\pop[5]Our group of heroes waits in the town square.
Eventually, as time passes, many of you start to lose hope.
The window of time for their arrival gets smaller and smaller.
If not, then how about we go on the offensive?
\pop[3]You mean take them down like we \c[14]originally\c[0] planned?
\pop[4]At least we gave them a \c[14]chance\c[0] for peace.
\pop[3]True. Sounds like a plan to me.
Been dying to put my sword arm to use again.
\pop[3]True. There hasn't been much fighting since the war.
Looks like your arms have gotten a bit smaller, Kyron.
You're about to give up hope, and \c[14]then\c[0]...
\pop[5]Someone approaches, from the far side of the square!
As promised, they came alone. Just in time, too.
\pop[4]You might want to use less aggressive wording.
My entire organization is built on the \c[14]truth\c[0].
The townspeople are starting to watch from afar.
\pop[3]Good thing they have nothing to worry about.
\pop[5]A tense atmosphere fills the town square.
The slowly setting sun offers lighting to increase the drama.
This was a standoff between the two best information brokers in the world.
\pop[4]I'm going to take slow steps toward you now.
I promise not to make any sudden movements.
\pop[4]In my pocket, is a paper that we stole from your quarters.
If we were to leak it, we'd have cause to take down The Thorns.
\pop[5]I take slow steps toward the leader of The Thorns.
\pop[4]I'm going to hand you the paper, and you can leave.
Go back to your HQ, and destroy all the intel you have on us.
We won't bother you, and you don't bother us.
Your Monarch would let The Thorns roam free?
If we took you down, someone else would just rise up.
\pop[4]So why not agree to put aside our differences?
Who knows, we might even need each other's help in the future.
\pop[5]I keep stepping forward, taking slow, cautious steps.
I know that any sudden movement could be seen as an attack.
\pop[5]But little did he know, that's exactly what I had planned.
When I get close enough, I reach into my pocket.
But instead of a paper, I pull out my \c[14]dagger\c[0]!
\pop[5]I grab the leader of The Thorns, holding them hostage.
I press the dagger against their throat, in anger.
I see two archers on the roof to the left.
And two more on the roof to my right.
\pop[5]I apply more pressure to his throat with the dagger.
\pop[4]Why did you skip out on our last meeting!?
I figured it out in your quarters.
\pop[3]Then perhaps you'd consider showing me mercy...
\pop[4]Not after what you did to me...!
I've been looking for you my \c[14]whole\c[0] life!
The leader of The Thorns is Isaac's father!
\pop[5]Oh, the irony! He abandoned his son to save him from the family business.
He didn't want Isaac to live his life surrounded by crime and deception.
\pop[5]But in doing so, he only \c[14]condemned\c[0] Isaac to that life from the start.
In the pursuit of finding his parents, he became the swindler he was today.
He embraced the very world that his parents tried to keep him out of.
\pop[4]You might not want to watch this...
Whatever happened, you can work it out!
\pop[4]I'm not budging on this one, Dante.
\pop[5]The whole group tries to talk Isaac down.
Especially when they were under the eyes of several archers.
\pop[5]I run the dagger across his throat, then throw him to the ground.
\pop[5]There's no time to act. The archers let loose in an act of revenge.
Isaac tries his best to dodge, but he's shot through the left shoulder.
\pop[5]In that moment, everyone flees from the town square.
Arrows rain down upon you, and you try your best to escape unharmed.
Isaac flees in the other direction, away from his friends.
In this moment, he chose revenge over his loyalty to The Monarchy.
\pop[5]Revenge for his father abandoning him as a child.
Revenge for every bad thing that ever happened in his life.
It didn't even matter to him that the townspeople watched in shock.
\pop[5]To them, they saw The Monarchy resort to assassination.
They'd never know who that was, or that The Thorns would fall apart.
You all escape unharmed, but several questions linger in the air.
\pop[5]What would happen to The Monarchy next?
What would the people think about your cause \c[14]now\c[0]?
Isaac's actions struck a blow to the integrity of \c[14]everything\c[0].
\pop[5]Did he \c[14]really\c[0] abandon you after taking his revenge?
Was everything that happened worth it? Is your rule in jeopardy?
\pop[5]I think \c[14]those\c[0] answers, we should save for the sequel...
